Sources should commonly describe such a band as having an important link. -->[[Vio-lence]] | website = {{URL|machinehead1.com}} | current_members = * [[Robb Flynn]] * [[Jared MacEachern]] | past_members = * [[Adam Duce]] * Tony Costanza * [[Logan Mader]] * [[Chris Kontos (musician)|Chris Kontos]] * [[Dave McClain (musician)|Dave McClain]] * [[Ahrue Luster]] * [[Phil Demmel]] }}
'''Machine Head''' is an American [[Heavy metal music|heavy metal]] band from [[Oakland, California|Oakland]], [[California]]. The band was formed in 1991 by vocalist/rhythm guitarist [[Robb Flynn]] and bassist [[Adam Duce]]. The band's aggressive musicianship made them one of the pioneering bands in the [[new wave of American heavy metal]].<ref name="Blabbermouth">{{cite web|title='New Wave Of American Heavy Metal' Book Documents Over 600 Bands |url=http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=44955 |publisher=Blabbermouth.net |accessdate=April 27, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080521104002/http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=44955 |archivedate=May 21, 2008 |df= }}</ref><ref name="metalexpressradio">{{cite web|url=http://www.metalexpressradio.com/menu.php?main=reviews&id=1013|publisher=Metal Express Radio|title=LAMB OF GOD - Burn The Priest|author=Shoegazer ross|accessdate=2008-05-06}}</ref> Machine Head's current lineup comprises Flynn and bassist [[Jared MacEachern]]; longtime drummer [[Dave McClain (musician)|Dave McClain]] and lead guitarist [[Phil Demmel]] will leave the band following their current tour.<ref name="bm final tour">{{cite web|title=MACHINE HEAD's PHIL DEMMEL And DAVE MCCLAIN To Leave Band After One Final U.S. Tour|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/machine-heads-phil-demmel-and-dave-mcclain-to-leave-band-after-one-final-u-s-tour/|publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|date=September 28, 2018|accessdate=September 28, 2018}}</ref><ref name="ug final tour">{{cite web|url=https://www.ultimate-guitar.com/news/general_music_news/longtime_members_phil_demmel__dave_mcclain_are_leaving_machine_head_after_one_final_tour.html|title=Longtime Members Phil Demmel & Dave McClain Are Leaving Machine Head After One Final Tour|publisher=[[Ultimate Guitar Archive|Ultimate-Guitar.com]]|date=September 29, 2018|accessdate=September 29, 2018}}</ref> Duce, lead guitarists [[Logan Mader]] and [[Ahrue Luster]] and drummers Tony Costanza and [[Chris Kontos (musician)|Chris Kontos]] are former members of the band.
Machine Head's first four albums earned the band a growing fan base in [[Europe]], however the band would not have success in the [[United States]] until later albums. The band drew controversy with its fourth album, ''[[Supercharger (album)|Supercharger]]'' (2001), which was released three weeks after the [[September 11 attacks]] and resulted in their songs and music video for the song "Crashing Around You" (which featured burning buildings) being pulled from all media outlets. The band nearly disbanded in 2002 after negotiating off its label [[Roadrunner Records]] as a result of the controversy, however the band would eventually re-sign with the label.
After experimenting with elements of [[groove metal]] and [[nu metal]] in their early releases, Machine Head changed to a more traditional [[thrash metal]] sound with its sixth album, ''[[The Blackening]]'' (2007), which drew critical acclaim and was chosen as Album of the Decade by ''[[Metal Hammer]]'' in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metalhammer.co.uk/news/albums-of-the-decade-machine-head-the-blackening/|title=Blog Archive » Albums Of The Decade: Machine Head – 'The Blackening'|work=Metal Hammer|date=July 23, 2009|accessdate=February 4, 2018}}</ref> The album's first single, "[[Aesthetics of Hate]]", also earned the band its first [[Grammy Award]] nomination. The band would continue to experiment with genres in later releases.
Machine Head has released nine studio albums, two live albums, one video album, 13 singles and 15 music videos. Four of the band's albums have been [[Music recording sales certification|certified silver]] in the [[United Kingdom]], and the band's highest peak on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] came with its eighth album, ''[[Bloodstone & Diamonds]]'' (2014), at number 21. To date, the band has sold over three million records worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ticketweb.com/t3/sale/SaleEventDetail?dispatch=loadSelectionData&eventId=3348284 |title=Tickets for Robb Flynn Of Machine Head : Acoustic Performance | Roxy Theatre at TicketWeb |publisher=Ticketweb.com |date=2013-01-21 |accessdate=2014-04-19}}</ref>
==History==
===Formation and ''Burn My Eyes'' (1991–1996)=== Machine Head were formed on October 12, 1991, in [[Oakland, California]] by vocalist/guitarist [[Robb Flynn]] and bassist [[Adam Duce]]. Flynn had recently parted ways with [[Vio-lence]] after a physical fight between the band members and a local gang. He still had a desire to write music and along with Duce recruited guitarist [[Logan Mader]] and drummer Tony Costanza to form Machine Head.<ref name="Revolver">{{cite journal| author=Wiederorn, Jon |date=May 2007 |title=Machine Head: Through the Ashes |journal=[[Revolver Magazine]]}}</ref> The band's name was thought of by Flynn because it "sounded cool", despite the popular belief that it came from the [[Deep Purple]] album of the [[Machine Head (album)|same name]].<ref name="TNN">{{cite web |author=Neff, Troy |url=http://www.theentertainmentnexus.com/interviews/rag/mcclainDave.htm |title=Dave McClain interview by Troy Neff |publisher=The Entertainment Nexus |accessdate=2008-02-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150120003637/http://www.theentertainmentnexus.com/interviews/rag/mcclainDave.htm |archivedate=2015-01-20 |df= }}</ref> The band started [[Jam (music)|jamming]] in a local warehouse shared with four [[punk rock]] bands.<ref name="MH1 bio">{{cite web|url=http://www.machinehead1.com/bio.html |title=Machine Head – Bio |publisher=Machinehead1.com |accessdate=2008-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071026020331/http://www.machinehead1.com/bio.html |archivedate=October 26, 2007 }}</ref> Machine Head recorded a [[Demo (music)|demo]] in a friend's bedroom, funded with US$800.<ref name="Revolver"/><ref name="MH1 bio"/> A record executive representing [[Roadrunner Records]] listened to the demo and signed the band.<ref name="Revolver"/>
Machine Head entered Fantasy Studios in [[Berkeley, California]] to record its debut album ''[[Burn My Eyes]]''.<ref name="Burn My Eyes">{{cite AV media notes| others=Machine Head |title=Burn My Eyes |date=1994-08-09 |publisher=[[Roadrunner Records]] |id=9016 |accessdate=2008-02-19}}</ref> Not long into production, Constanza left the band and was replaced by [[Chris Kontos (musician)|Chris Kontos]]. Most of the songs on the album were songs written by Flynn and Duce during the time Flynn was not in a band, about "being pissed off" from his previous struggles in Vio-lence, as well as both of their battles with illegal drugs.<ref name="Revolver"/> Produced by [[Colin Richardson]], the album was released on August 9, 1994. The album shipped nearly 400,000 copies worldwide, becoming Roadrunner Records' best selling debut album.<ref name="Revolver"/> [[Allmusic]] reviewer John Franck stated "''Burn My Eyes'' is a bone-shattering exercise in brutality".<ref name="BME AMG">{{cite web| author=Franck, John |url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r206602|pure_url=yes}} |title=''Burn My Eyes'' review |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=2008-02-21}}</ref>
Not long after ''Burn My Eyes'''s release Machine Head started touring heavily in support of the album, opening for [[Slayer]] in Europe in the latter half of 1994, a tour which ended with their own headline show at the [[London Astoria]]. Following the success of the support tour the band returned to Europe for a headline tour in early 1995, performing in the same venues they opened for Slayer.<ref name="Abslut Adam">{{cite web| url=http://www.absolutmetal.com/AdamInterview.htm |title=Machine Head interview with Adam Duce |publisher=Absolutmetal.com |date=1997-10-23 |accessdate=2008-02-22}}</ref> The band would return to Europe for the summer festival season but Kontos refused to tour and the band drafted Walter Ryan for the festival dates.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c0R9wfEPxeE |title=Machine Head - 02 BLOOD FOR BLOOD live @ Donington Park, Donington, England 1995-08-26 - YouTube |publisher=Uk.youtube.com |accessdate=2011-10-22}}</ref> On the band's return to the US Kontos was fired because he was not keeping to touring commitments. Kontos went on to play drums with [[Testament (band)|Testament]], and was replaced by [[Dave McClain (drummer)|Dave McClain]].
===''The More Things Change...'' and ''The Burning Red'' (1997–2000)=== After touring for ''Burn My Eyes'', Machine Head entered the studio to record its second studio album, ''[[The More Things Change...]]'', with Richardson producing and mixing for a second time. The album was released on March 25, 1997, and debuted at number 138 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] albums chart.<ref name="Billboard">{{cite web|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=machine head|chart=all}} |title=Artist chart history |publisher=[[Billboard charts]] |accessdate=2008-02-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150628212934/http://www.billboard.com/artist/276909/machine%2Bhead/chart |archivedate=June 28, 2015 |df= }}</ref> Machine Head toured in Europe with [[Napalm Death]], [[Coal Chamber]] and [[Skinlab]], then went on the first [[Ozzfest]] for the first tours in support of the album.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ozzfest.com/static_content/view/alumni.html |title=Ozzfest alumini |publisher=Ozzfest.com |accessdate=2008-01-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080103010421/http://www.ozzfest.com/static_content/view/alumni.html |archivedate=January 3, 2008 }}</ref> Mader showed up to a practice session late, high on [[methamphetamine]], cursing at and insulting the band members; and quit the band later that day. [[Ahrue Luster]] replaced him and finished touring,<ref name="Revolver"/><ref name="Luster leaves">{{cite web| url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/former-machine-head-guitarist-says-his-dictatorship-comment-was-a-misquote/|title=Former Machine Head guitarist says his "dictatorship" comment was a misquote |publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]] |date=2003-02-12 |accessdate=2008-02-23}}</ref> while Mader toured with [[Soulfly]] in support of their [[Soulfly (album)|self-titled debut album]].
After three years of touring and working with producer [[Ross Robinson]], Machine Head released its third studio album, ''[[The Burning Red]]'', on August 10, 1999. The band added new elements to its music, including [[rapping]] vocals, a move which some believe to have been influenced by [[Ahrue Luster]] himself.<ref name="Revolver"/> This album, along with the band's change in image and musical direction was highly criticized, with critics and fans alike accusing the band of "[[selling out]]".<ref name="Revolver"/> Nevertheless, McClain stated they weren't trying to sound like popular bands but "wanted to sound different".<ref name="Revolver"/> Rick Anderson of Allmusic stated Machine Head was "sounding a bit looser and less constricted musically than they have in the past".<ref name="TBR AMG">{{cite web| author=Anderson, Rick |url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r424189|pure_url=yes}} |title=''The Burning Red'' overview |publisher=Allmusic |accessdate=2008-02-23}}</ref> ''The Burning Red'' became Machine Head's top selling album for a number of years, and debuted at number 88 on the ''Billboard'' 200.<ref name="Billboard"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=3145 |title=Metal/Hard Rock Album Sales In The US As Reported By SoundScan |publisher=Blabbermouth.net |date=2002-04-30 |accessdate=2008-02-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606225912/http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=3145 |archivedate=2011-06-06 |df= }}</ref>
===''Supercharger'' and ''Through the Ashes of Empires'' (2001–2005)=== Machine Head finished touring for ''The Burning Red'', and entered a studio with producer [[Johnny K]] to record ''[[Supercharger (album)|Supercharger]]''. Debuting at number 115 on the ''Billboard'' 200, the album was released on October 2, 2001.<ref name="Billboard"/> The album met the same criticism as ''The Burning Red'', especially for the ever-present rapping vocals. [[Blabbermouth.net]] reviewer Borivoj Krgin stated ''Supercharger'' "is likely to disappoint everyone who is expecting the Bay Area quartet to return to the ultra-testosterone-charged sounds of their first two albums".<ref name="SC BMN">{{cite web |author=Krgin, Borivoj |url=http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/showreview.aspx?reviewID=51 |title=CD reviews – Machine Head ''Supercharger'' |publisher=Blabbermouth.net |accessdate=2008-02-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081017232045/http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/showreview.aspx?reviewID=51 |archivedate=2008-10-17 |df= }}</ref> [[File:Phil Demmel 2.jpg|thumb|upright|Guitarist Phil Demmel performing with Machine Head in 2009.]] Machine Head released a single for "[[Crashing Around You]]" as well as a music video. The video was released several weeks after the [[September 11, 2001 attacks]], and was banned from [[MTV]] for the depictions of falling buildings. Roadrunner Records, expecting to make a fair profit from album promotions, dropped the band's funding, causing Machine Head to leave the label.<ref name="Metalunderground">{{cite web| url=http://www.metalunderground.com/interviews/details.cfm?newsid=9004 |title=Interview With Machine Head's Phil Demmel |publisher=Metalunderground.com |date=2007-08-12 |accessdate=2007-11-21}}</ref> At the same time the band was leaving Roadrunner, Luster departed from the band for musical differences.
By 2002, Machine Head had sold over 1.3 million albums worldwide, and overall ''Supercharger'' (mixed by Colin Richardson) would go on to sell 250,000 copies worldwide, which was their lowest selling album to date. Once the tour for the album had been completed, Machine Head and Roadrunner Records mutually decided to sever ties with regards to distribution in North America and around the world, however to fill the ties, the band released ''[[Hellalive]]'' (also mixed by Colin Richardson) which was a recording of a Brixton Academy, London set.
In 2002 Ahrue Luster left the band and was temporarily replaced by Phil Demmel, who played in thrash band Vio-lence alongside Flynn. Demmel played some festival shows with Machine Head (including a headlining slot at the With Full Force festival in Germany). Then with Phil not being able to commit to the band, he and Machine Head parted ways. The remainder of the band starting writing songs for the next album (eventually ''Through the Ashes...''), and hoping to get signed to a record label. They recorded a short demo, including a radio-style song called "Pins and Needles", and an Electronic Press Kit for the companies, also hoping they can get signed on the strength of their previous efforts. Nearly every record label in the music industry rejected the four track demo.
After Machine Head's European tour, Ahrue Luster returned to his family business and the band started writing together as a three-piece, while leaving a position open for Demmel. In March 2003, Demmel joined Machine Head as a full-time guitarist and started writing with the band. By June 2003, Machine Head entered a studio with Flynn producing.<ref name="lambgoat">{{cite web|author=Unrest, Kirby |date=January 2005 |url=http://www.lambgoat.com/features/interviews/machine_head.aspx |title=Machine Head interview |publisher=Lambgoat.com |accessdate=2008-02-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071226174652/http://www.lambgoat.com/features/interviews/machine_head.aspx |archivedate=December 26, 2007 }}</ref> On October 27, 2003, Machine Head released ''[[Through the Ashes of Empires]]'' in Europe.
The band was turned down by multiple record labels in the United States, until Roadrunner USA, interested in the new album, offered Machine Head another record contract. Machine Head accepted the offer on the grounds that the band owns 100% of the music. On April 20, 2004, ''Through the Ashes of Empires'' was released in the United States with a bonus track for the Americans' long wait for the album's release.<ref name="lambgoat"/> The album debuted at number 88 on the ''Billboard'' 200.<ref name="Billboard"/> The band released a single for "Imperium", the video for which received heavy rotation on MTV. Eduardo Rivadavia of [[AllMusic]] stated ''Through the Ashes of Empires'' "marked a return to form in no uncertain terms".<ref name="TTAOF">{{cite web| author=Rivadavia, Eduardo |url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r678309|pure_url=yes}} |title=''Through the Ashes of Empires'' overview |publisher=Allmusic |accessdate=2008-02-26}}</ref>
Machine Head headlined the True Metal stage at the 2005 [[Wacken Open Air]] festival to 40,000 fans—the band's largest headlining crowd at the time.<ref>{{cite web| author=Flynn, Robb |url=http://www.machinehead1.com/diary.html |title=Machine Head diary |publisher=Machinehead1.com |accessdate=2008-02-25}}</ref> The band released a DVD containing a full sold-out concert held at the [[Brixton Academy]] in December 2004, a documentary, and music videos. The DVD debuted at number 13 on the U.S. music video charts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/esearch/chart_display.jsp?cfi=383&cfgn=Videos&cfn=Billboard+Comprehensive+Music+Videos&ci=3062015&cdi=8462966&cid=10%2F29%2F2005 |title=Billboard Comprehensive Music Videos – ''Elegies'' |publisher=Billboard charts |accessdate=2008-02-25 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071211170854/http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/esearch/chart_display.jsp?cfi=383&cfgn=Videos&cfn=Billboard%2BComprehensive%2BMusic%2BVideos&ci=3062015&cdi=8462966&cid=10%2F29%2F2005 |archivedate=December 11, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> They also played in Dubai for the annual [[Dubai Desert Rock Festival]] in 2005. This was their first show in the Middle East. The band also played at the farewell concert of [[Böhse Onkelz]] on the Euro Speedway Lausitz.
===''The Blackening'' (2006–2009)=== Machine Head's sixth studio album, titled ''[[The Blackening]]'', was released in North America on March 27, 2007. It entered the ''Billboard'' 200 at number 53, the highest charting position for the band at that time, with first-week sales of 15,000.<ref name="MACHINE HEAD: 'The Blackening' Enters Italian Chart At No. 55">{{cite web |title=Machine Head: ''The Blackening'' enters Italian chart at No. 55 |publisher=Blabbermouth.net |date=2007-04-23 |url=http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=71033 |accessdate=2007-08-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071001000000/http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=71033 |archivedate=2007-10-01 |df= }}</ref> It also made the top 20 in several European countries. Robb Flynn stated during an interview that the band are fans of [[Rush (band)|Rush]] and received a great deal of influence from their album ''[[A Farewell to Kings]]'' while creating ''The Blackening''.
The album received positive reviews from music critics, with some labeling it the best metal album of 2007. Blabbermouth.net reviewer Don Kaye awarded the album a 9.5 out of 10, saying ''The Blackening'' is "one of the purest, finest, most powerful expressions of modern heavy metal released" and compared it to the 1986 [[Metallica]] album ''[[Master of Puppets]]'',<ref name="Blabbermouth - The Blackening">{{cite web|title=Blabbermouth - ''The Blackening'' review |author=Kaye, Don |publisher=Blabbermouth.net |url=http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/showreview.aspx?reviewID=1066 |accessdate=2007-08-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071015224258/http://roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/showreview.aspx?reviewID=1066 |archivedate=2007-10-15 |df= }}</ref> while Allmusic editor Thom Jurek described the album as "an over the top rage and pummelfest with all the qualities that earned the group its enormous fan base by touring and recording", praising the songs "Beautiful Mourning", "[[Halo (Machine Head song)|Halo]]", and "[[Now I Lay Thee Down]]".<ref name="Allmusic - The Blackening">{{cite web |title=Allmusic - ''The Blackening'' |author=Jurek, Thom |publisher=Allmusic |url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r1023773|pure_url=yes}} |accessdate=2007-08-03}}</ref> ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' reviewer Andy Greene, however, responded negatively as he was displeased with the songs running over ten minutes.<ref name="The Blackening - Rolling Stone">{{cite web |title=''The Blackening'' - ''Rolling Stone'' |author=Greene, Andy |work=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=2007-03-21 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/reviews/album/13885770/review/13891164 |accessdate=2007-08-03|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071014060825/http://rollingstone.com/reviews/album/13885770/review/13891164|archivedate=14 October 2007|deadurl=yes}}</ref>
Machine Head toured North America with [[Lamb of God (band)|Lamb of God]], [[Trivium (band)|Trivium]] and [[Gojira (band)|Gojira]] in early 2007 to promote ''The Blackening'', and opened for [[Megadeth]] and [[Heaven & Hell (band)|Heaven & Hell]] in April 2007. A European tour saw the band make an appearance at the [[Download Festival]] in [[Donington Park]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=74311 |title=Machine Head at UK's Download Festival; video available |publisher=Blabbermouth.net |date=2008-06-09 |accessdate=2008-02-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080228004940/http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=74311 |archivedate=2008-02-28 |df= }}</ref> Shortly after, the band announced a co-headlining tour of Japan, Europe, and Australia titled The Black Crusade from October to December. Other bands on the bill included Trivium, [[Arch Enemy (band)|Arch Enemy]], [[DragonForce]] (Europe only) and [[Shadows Fall]] (Europe only).<ref>{{cite journal|date=January 2008 |title=The Black Crusade – Chaos Reigns |journal=[[Metal Hammer]] Magazine }}</ref> On June 12, 2007, at the [[Metal Hammer Golden Gods Awards]], the band won the award for "Best Album", and Flynn won the "Golden God" award.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=75009 |title=Machine Head: Footage from ''Metal Hammer'' Golden Gods awards |publisher=Blabbermouth.net |date=2007-06-27 |accessdate=2008-02-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081017232016/http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=75009 |archivedate=2008-10-17 |df= }}</ref> Machine Head also won Best Album at the [[Kerrang! Awards 2007]]. The band replaced [[Bullet For My Valentine]] supporting Metallica's [[Wembley Stadium]] show on Sunday July 8, 2007, as Bullet For My Valentine's vocalist Matt Tuck required a [[tonsillectomy]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=83324 |title=Machine Head frontman talks about playing with Metallica, hanging out with Lars Ulrich |publisher=Blabbermouth.net |date=2007-10-23 |accessdate=2008-02-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090218165211/http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=83324 |archivedate=2009-02-18 |df= }}</ref> Machine Head also toured North America with [[Hellyeah]], [[Nonpoint]] and [[Bury Your Dead]] in early 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=90726 |title=Machine Head drummer to rejoin bandmates tomorrow |publisher=Blabbermouth.net |date=2008-02-14 |accessdate=2008-02-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080217153210/http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=90726 |archivedate=2008-02-17 |df= }}</ref> Machine Head recently completed a world tour where they played [[Bengaluru]], India, Israel and [[Dubai]], [[U.A.E.]] in March 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.metalisrael.com/?p=611|title=Betzefer/Machine Head 10 March 2008 Jerusalem Post review |publisher=metalisrael.com |date=2008-03-17 |accessdate=2008-03-17}}</ref> [[File:Robb Flynn Rotterdam 2009 02.jpg|thumb|left|Robb Flynn of Machine Head as support band for Metallica in Rotterdam 2009.]] In October 2008 the band toured in Australia with Slipknot.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.fasterlouder.com.au/reviews/events/15515/Slipknot-Machine-Head-Sydonia-Rod-Laver-Arena-Melbourne-27102008|title=Slipknot, Machinehead, Sydonia @ Rod Laver Arena, Melbourne, 27/10/2008 |date=October 2008 |accessdate=2015-02-03}}</ref> The band then toured Europe with [[Slipknot (band)|Slipknot]] and [[Children of Bodom]] in November and December.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ultimate-guitar.com/news/upcoming_tours/slipknot_machine_head_children_of_bodom_more_tour_dates.html|title=Slipknot, Machinehead, Children of Bodom, More Tour Dates |date=June 11, 2008 |accessdate=2015-02-03}}</ref> The band recorded a version of [[Iron Maiden]]'s classic, "[[Hallowed Be Thy Name]]" for a ''[[Kerrang!]]'' tribute compilation album, entitled ''[[Maiden Heaven: A Tribute to Iron Maiden]]''; this song was played live multiple times since its release and has become a permanent in their current touring setlists. Amongst other bands who appeared on the album were label mates, [[Dream Theater]] and [[Trivium (band)|Trivium]].
It was announced on August 10, 2008 that Machine Head and [[Austin, Texas]] based band [[The Sword]] would be opening for Metallica at ten shows in January 2009. In a recent interview conducted with Phil Demmel, he revealed that with Machine Head's upcoming touring commitments, the band would not have chance to write a follow up album until at least 2010, for an expected 2011 release date.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.metalunderground.com/news/details.cfm?newsid=38676 |title=Machine Head Will Not Release An Album Until 2011 |publisher=Metalunderground.com |date=2008-08-29 |accessdate=2008-09-28}}</ref> Machine Head toured with [[The Sword (band)|The Sword]] in Metallica's World Magnetic Tour for the ''[[Death Magnetic]]'' album from 2008 to 2009. Machine Head also opened for [[Megadeth]], [[Slayer]] and [[Suicide Silence]] on the Canadian Carnage tour in late June.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.Net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=118898 |title=MEGADETH And SLAYER To Co-Headline 'Canadian Carnage' Trek |publisher=Roadrunnerrecords.com |accessdate=2011-10-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110914085526/http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.Net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=118898 |archivedate=2011-09-14 |df= }}</ref> Machine Head reportedly cancelled their appearance at Sonisphere Festival in the UK because they had disagreements with the staff over their slot. They thought they should play after [[Limp Bizkit]]. However, a week before the Sonisphere festival took place on August 1 and 2, Machine Head agreed to take back their slot below Limp Bizkit. Their appearance was kept secret until the day they played. In August 2009, they won the Inspiration Award at the 2009 Kerrang! Awards.<ref name="kerrang awards">{{cite web|url=http://www2.kerrang.com/2009/08/the_2009_kerrang_awards_winner.html |title=The 2009 Kerrang! Awards winners |publisher=Kerrang! |date=August 3, 2009 |accessdate=2009-08-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090806191651/http://www2.kerrang.com/2009/08/the_2009_kerrang_awards_winner.html |archivedate=August 6, 2009 |df= }}</ref> It was announced on the August 31 that Machine Head would tour through Europe and UK in 2010 with [[Hatebreed]], [[Bleeding Through]], and [[All Shall Perish]] in what will be known as "The Black Procession", as well as adding dates for an Australian and New Zealand tour cycle in March. This will be the last time the band tour in support of ''The Blackening'' before writing the next album, as Dave McClain described in an interview, before their Belfast show in Northern Ireland.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://giggingni.com/site/interview.php?id=32 |title=Giggingni interview |publisher=Giggingni.com |accessdate=2013-02-23 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100406122016/http://giggingni.com/site/interview.php?id=32 |archivedate=2010-04-06}}</ref>

In a November 2012 interview, Machine Head guitarist Phil Demmel revealed that the band planned to begin writing new material for their eighth studio album in 2013 and hopes that they will begin recording it before the end of that year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=183009|title=Machine Head To Begin Writing New Album Early Next Year|date=November 30, 2012|publisher=Blabbermouth.net}}</ref>
===''Bloodstone & Diamonds'' (2013–2015)=== On February 22, 2013, the band announced that bassist/founding member Adam Duce left the band, albeit on friendly terms. 4 days later, Robb Flynn revealed in his online blog that he fired Adam Duce because of ongoing differences. His departure makes Flynn the only remaining original member.<ref name="Machine Head official web page">{{cite web|url=http://machinehead1.com/board_posts/machine-head-and-bassist-adam-duce-part-ways |title=Machine Head - Machine Head and Bassist Adam Duce Part Ways |publisher=Machinehead1.com |accessdate=2013-02-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130225033719/http://machinehead1.com/board_posts/machine-head-and-bassist-adam-duce-part-ways |archivedate=2013-02-25 |df= }}</ref> As of March 2013, ''[[Unto the Locust]]'' has sold 100,000 copies in the United States, making it their third quickest-selling album behind ''[[The Blackening]]'' and ''[[Supercharger (album)|Supercharger]]'' which have sold 260,000 in two weeks and 250,000 copies in 4 months in the United States respectively. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/MachineHead/posts/10151346478933823 |title=Machine Head - The General Journals: Diary Of A... |publisher=Facebook |accessdate=2014-04-19}}</ref> The band began the process of searching for a temporary bassist for the 2013 Rockstar Energy Drink [[Mayhem Festival]] in the U.S. For a limited time, the band accepted and reviewed [[YouTube]] submissions.<ref>{{cite web|title=MACHINE HEAD To Start Bassist Auditions|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=187995|publisher=BlabberMouth}}</ref> On June 24, 2013 the band announced that former [[Sanctity (band)|Sanctity]] rhythm guitarist and vocalist [[Jared MacEachern]] has joined the band as their new bassist. [[Robb Flynn]] said of MacEachern: "[[Monte Conner]] recommended Jared since he was already on the tour, and that ended up being a great call. Jared flew out a few days before the tour and rehearsed with us and did great." [[Phil Demmel]] continued: — "There were dozens of amazing players, and it was interesting to watch each one take on our tunes. One of our biggest criteria for this gig was to be able to sing the high harmonies. That was our litmus test. And Jared passed with flying colors.".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://machinehead1.com/board_posts/machine-head-announces-new-bassist|title=Machine Head announce new bassist|publisher=Machinehead1.com|accessdate=2014-04-19|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203042150/http://machinehead1.com/board_posts/machine-head-announces-new-bassist|archivedate=2013-12-03|df=}}</ref>
On October 2, 2013 the band announced that it signed to Nuclear Blast.<ref>{{cite web|title=MACHINE HEAD Signs With NUCLEAR BLAST ENTERTAINMENT|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/machine-head-signs-with-nuclear-blast-entertainment/|publisher=Blabbermouth.net}}</ref> In February 2014, the band entered the studio to record their new album, ''[[Bloodstone & Diamonds]]'', for a late summer release.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/machine-heads-robb-flynn-says-new-songs-are-definitely-moving-bands-sound-forward/|title=Machine Head's Robb Flynn says new songs are 'definitely' moving band's sound forward|publisher=Blabbermouth.net|accessdate=2014-04-19}}</ref>
In early 2014, Duce filed a lawsuit against his former band and manager in federal court "for trademark infringement, breach of fiduciary duty, breach of partnership agreement, intentional and negligent interference with prospective economic relations, negligence, defamation and unfair competition, and he wants the band enjoined from using the Machine Head marks."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.courthousenews.com/2014/01/15/64541.htm |title=Courthouse News Service |publisher=Courthousenews.com |date=2014-01-15 |accessdate=2014-04-19}}</ref> The lawsuit was settled out of court on July 2 with undisclosed terms.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/machine-head-settles-lawsuit-filed-by-former-bassist-adam-duce/ |title=MACHINE HEAD Settles Lawsuit Filed By Former Bassist ADAM DUCE|publisher=Blabbermouth.net|date=2014-07-03|accessdate=2014-07-03}}</ref> In August 2014, Robb Flynn announced the track listing for ''Bloodstone & Diamonds'', consisting of 12 tracks along with its artwork.<ref name="Tracks and artwork">{{cite web|last1=Carter|first1=Emily|title=Machine Head announce new album, !Bloodstone & Diamonds!|url=http://www.kerrang.com/21569/machine-head-announce-new-album-bloodstone-diamonds/|website=Kerrang.com|publisher=Kerrang!|accessdate=18 August 2014}}</ref>
''[[Bloodstone & Diamonds]]'' was released in November 2014 to positive reviews from fans and critics alike, with many saying how the addition of MacEachern brought a sense of rejuvenation to the band. The band embarked on a lengthy world tour in support of the album, including a leg of European shows, two American legs and various others in Japan, Australia and New Zealand.
===''Catharsis'' and lineup changes (2016–present)=== On June 1, 2016, a stand-alone single titled "Is There Anybody Out There?" premiered on [[Sirius XM Octane]], and on June 3 the single was available for digital download. On March 17, 2017, the band were featured on American horror movie [[The Devil's Candy]]'s soundtrack along with [[Ghost (Swedish band)|Ghost]] and [[Slayer]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/slayer-ghost-machine-head-featured-on-the-devils-candy-soundtrack/|title=SLAYER, GHOST, MACHINE HEAD Featured On 'The Devil's Candy' Soundtrack}}</ref>
In June 2017, it was reported that Machine Head was in the studio working on new material.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theprp.com/2017/06/03/news/machine-head-seem-studio/|title=Machine Head Seem To Be In The Studio|website=theprp.com|date=3 June 2017|accessdate=4 June 2017}}</ref> In September 2017, the band announced the new album ''[[Catharsis (Machine Head album)|Catharsis]]'' for a January 2018 release with an accompanying world tour.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.metalsucks.net/2017/09/18/machine-head-announce-new-album-tour-dates/|title=Machine Head Announce New Album + Tour Dates|website=metalsucks.net|date=18 September 2017|accessdate=19 September 2017}}</ref>
On September 28, 2018, Robb Flynn posted a live video on [[Facebook]] to explain that Demmel and McClain had left Machine Head earlier in the week, but that they would both complete the band's current tour.<ref name="bm final tour"/><ref>[https://www.facebook.com/MachineHead/videos/1858060600973982/?__xts__[0]=68.ARAlRK9uzm7iWn-DbArr7z-Yrywhixobs7h64PTwzlGFdeKfCHbZmOsTSAUnIV4n-HNtT5aqB80cRpATcGy_t59Qf2Lu2sEqYNhWqUNrxqhQJqVYxdwAU7ptVpWRJXT5bgapRD-K0PbCjtE48igE-u0bRWOVx8s1NohnB2I83nhYCBiRY0kkYw&__tn__=-R Machine Head announcement] Machine Head on Facebook. 28 September 2018. Retrieved 28 September 2018.</ref> The announcement was mistakenly reported on by news sources as a disbandment, due to Flynn's referral to the current run of shows as a "farewell tour". Flynn later clarified that "this is the farewell tour of this lineup, this era of Machine Head. This is not the farewell tour of Machine Head."<ref name="ug final tour"/>
==Musical style, influences and legacy== Machine Head has been mainly described as [[groove metal]]<ref>{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p290888|pure_url=yes}} |title=Face Down {{!}} Biography & History |last=Rivadavia |first=Eduardo |publisher=[[AllMusic]] |accessdate=September 19, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.altpress.com/reviews/entry/prayforvillains/|title=AP – DevilDriver – Pray For Villains|last=Schruers|first=Jason|work=[[Alternative Press (music magazine)|Alternative Press]]|accessdate=September 19, 2017|date=May 20, 2010}}</ref> [[thrash metal]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://exclaim.ca/music/article/machine_heads_robb_flynn |title=Machine Head's Robb Flynn |last=Pratt |first=Greg |date=September 26, 2011 |work=[[Exclaim!]] |accessdate=September 19, 2017}}</ref> [[Heavy metal music|heavy metal]],<ref name="Blabbermouth"/><ref name="metalexpressradio"/> and [[nu metal]].<ref>{{cite web|first= Jeremy |last= Vane-Tempest |title= Machine Head: Bloodstone & Diamond |website= Mind Equals Blown |date= November 13, 2014 |accessdate=August 2, 2018|url= http://mindequalsblown.net/reviews/machine-head-bloodstone-diamonds}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|first= Marty |last= Dodge |title= Music Reviews: Christ Agony, Clutch, Freedom Call, Machine Head and Some Indie |website= [[Blogcritics]] |date= April 23, 2007 |accessdate=August 2, 2018|url= http://blogcritics.org/music-reviews-christ-agony-clutch-freedom/}}</ref> The band is influenced by Californian thrash metal bands such as {{nowrap|[[Vio-lence]],}} [[Metallica]], [[Exodus (American band)|Exodus]], [[Slayer]] and [[Testament (band)|Testament]], crossover thrash bands [[Suicidal Tendencies]] and [[Cro-Mags]], groove metal bands [[Pantera]] and [[Exhorder]], and grunge bands [[Nirvana (band)|Nirvana]], [[Soundgarden]] and [[Alice in Chains]].<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TfFnSorGczc&feature=relmfu |title=Interview Machine Head - Robb Flynn (part 2) |publisher=YouTube |date=2011-01-07 |accessdate=2012-04-15}}</ref>
Their early albums ''[[Burn My Eyes]]'' and ''[[The More Things Change...]]'' show a groove metal and thrash metal approach, similar to bands like [[Pantera]] and [[Exhorder]]. The albums also featured technical drumming by [[Chris Kontos (musician)|Chris Kontos]] and [[Dave McClain (drummer)|Dave McClain]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metal-archives.com/reviews/Machine_Head/Burn_My_Eyes/1508/ |title=Encyclopaedia Metallum: The Metal Archives - Machine Head - Burn My Eyes - Reviews |publisher=The Metal Archives |accessdate=2012-04-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://sputnikmusic.com/review/27367/Machine-Head-The-More-Things-Change.../ |title=Machine Head - The More Things Change... (album review) |publisher=Sputnikmusic |date=2008-09-28 |accessdate=2012-04-15}}</ref> The band changed their musical direction for the albums ''[[The Burning Red]]'' (1999) and ''[[Supercharger (album)|Supercharger]]'' (2001), which have been described as displaying a [[nu metal]] sound.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Rosenberg|first1=Axl|title=ROB FLYNN, HYPOCRITE?|url=http://www.metalsucks.net/2009/08/17/rob-flynn-hypocrite/|website=MetalSucks|accessdate=March 21, 2015|date=August 17, 2009|quote=But there’s just no getting around it: some of these albums are terrible, and the band definitely looked, sounded, and felt like a crappy nu-metal outfit...}}</ref> These albums featured [[rapping]] by [[Robb Flynn]] and simpler guitar riffs, but retaining part of their aggressive sound. This change in direction resulted in criticism from many fans because of the popularity of nu metal at the time.<ref name=amg>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r424189/review|pure_url=yes}}|title=The Burning Red - Machine Head|publisher=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nolifetilmetal.com/machinehead.htm |title=No Life 'til Metal - CD Gallery - Machine Head |publisher=Nolifetilmetal.com |accessdate=2013-02-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rocknworld.com/thrashpit/reviews/07/MachineHead.shtml |title=Machine Head - The Burning Red Review - Thrashpit.com |publisher=Rocknworld.com |accessdate=2013-02-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.metaljudgment.com/albums/machinehead_supercharger.html |title=The Album Review : Supercharger : Machine Head |publisher=Metaljudgement.com |accessdate=2014-04-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131109110515/http://www.metaljudgment.com/albums/machinehead_supercharger.html |archivedate=2013-11-09 |df= }}</ref>
Machine Head returned to the groove metal and thrash metal sound of the first two albums with the album ''[[Through the Ashes of Empires]]'', which proved a success.{{Citation needed|date=August 2015|reason=True, but we need a citation here to meet quality}}
Machine Head increased the complexity and technicality in their sound for the next album, ''[[The Blackening]]'', which partially changes the sound of their first 5 albums in favor of a more classic heavy metal and thrash metal oriented sound, with fully complex song structures and guitar riffs.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.ultimate-guitar.com/reviews/compact_discs/machine_head/the_blackening/index.html |title=The Blackening Review | Machine Head | Compact Discs | Reviews @ |publisher=Ultimate-guitar.com |accessdate=2012-04-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guitarmasterclass.net/wiki/index.php/Machine_Head#Discography |title=Machine Head |publisher=Guitarmasterclass.net |date=2008-06-27 |accessdate=2012-04-15}}</ref> ''[[Unto the Locust]]'' features heavier, faster and more complex riffs by both Robb Flynn and [[Phil Demmel]], influenced by classical music, and supported by fast and complex drum patterns by Dave McClain. This is also the first Machine Head's record to include [[blast beats]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Hitler |first=Crack |url=http://frankryanblog.blogspot.in/2011/09/machine-head-unto-locust-710.html?zx=9aff30dbc374aa51 |title=Wank Ryan: Machine Head - Unto The Locust [7/10] |publisher=Frankryanblog.blogspot.in |date=2011-09-19 |accessdate=2012-04-15}}</ref>
Robb Flynn makes use of different vocal styles including [[singing|clean vocals]], [[screaming (music)|screams]] and [[death growls]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ultimate-guitar.com/reviews/compact_discs/machine_head/unto_the_locust/index.html |title=Unto The Locust Review | Machine Head | Compact Discs | Reviews @ |publisher=Ultimate-guitar.com |accessdate=2012-04-15}}</ref>; Flynn himself has jokingly called his own singing style "barking in key".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/MachineHead/posts/10151875763918823|title=Machine Head|website=www.facebook.com}}</ref>
Machine Head is one of the bands that support the [[New Wave of American Heavy Metal]]<ref name="Influence2">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p516160|pure_url=yes}}|title=allmusic (((Mastodon > Biography)))|last=Monger|first=James Christopher|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|accessdate=July 13, 2010}}</ref> and influenced bands such as [[Slipknot (band)|Slipknot]], [[Hatebreed]], [[Lamb of God (band)|Lamb of God]], [[Shadows Fall]], [[Bullet for My Valentine]], [[DevilDriver]], [[Gojira (band)|Gojira]], [[Trivium (band)|Trivium]], [[Hatriot]], [[Killswitch Engage]], [[Chimaira]], [[The Black Dahlia Murder (band)|The Black Dahlia Murder]], [[Throwdown (band)|Throwdown]], [[Rise to Remain]], and [[Suicide Silence]].

{{distinguish|Email}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2018}} {{Infobox website | name = MailOnline | logo = Mail Online.png | url = {{URL|https://dailymail.co.uk}} | commercial = Yes | type = {{hlist | [[Entertainment]] | [[Lifestyle (sociology)|lifestyle]] | [[personal finance]]}} | registration = Optional | language = [[English language|English]] | owner = [[Daily Mail and General Trust]] | launch_date = 2003 | alexa = {{Decrease}} 162 ({{as of|2017|9|23|alt=September 2017}})<ref name="alexa">{{cite web|url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/dailymail.co.uk |title= Dailymail.co.uk Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 1 April 2014 }}</ref> | current status = Active }} '''MailOnline''' (also known as '''''dailymail.co.uk''''') is the website of the ''[[Daily Mail]]'', a newspaper in the [[United Kingdom]], and of its sister paper ''[[The Mail on Sunday]]''. MailOnline is a division of DMG Media, part of [[Associated Newspapers|Associated Newspapers Ltd]].
Launched in 2003, MailOnline was made into a separately managed site in 2006 under the editorship of Martin Clarke and general management of James Bromley.<ref>{{cite web|title=How ‘Journalism Crack’ Conquered the Internet|url=http://observer.com/2014/03/mailonline/ |website= The Observer |accessdate= 14 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://gigaom.com/2008/10/21/419-newspapers-merge-sales-teams-bromley-to-lead-mail-online/|title=DMGT, News Int Merge Sales Teams, Bromley To Lead Mail Online|last=Andrews|first=Robert|date=21 October 2008|website=gigaom.com|language=en-US|access-date=21 May 2018}}</ref> It is now the most visited English-language newspaper website in the world,<ref name=FT20140924>{{cite news | url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/cf2e53d2-425e-11e4-a9f4-00144feabdc0.html | title=MailOnline and the next page for the ‘sidebar of shame’ | first=Henry | last=Mance | date=24 September 2014 | newspaper=Financial Times | accessdate=25 December 2014 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150418010133/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/cf2e53d2-425e-11e4-a9f4-00144feabdc0.html | archive-date = 18 April 2015 | dead-url = yes }}</ref> with over 11.34m visitors daily in August 2014.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.mediaweek.co.uk/article/1313132/newspaper-abcs-digital-figures-august-2014 | title=Newspaper ABCs: Digital figures for August 2014 | first=Joel | last= Fothergill | date=19 September 2014 | newspaper=Media Week | accessdate=25 December 2014}}</ref>
==Reach==
The website has an international readership, featuring separate home pages for the UK, USA, India and Australia.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mail Online to launch in Australia with Mi9|url=http://www.mediaweek.co.uk/article/1222686/mail-online-launch-australia-mi9|accessdate=31 January 2014|newspaper=MediaWeek|date=26 November 2013}}</ref> While the MailOnline maintains the conservative editorial stance of the print edition, much of the content featured on the website is produced exclusively for the MailOnline and is not published in the ''Daily Mail''. It is known for its "[[Sidebar (publishing)|sidebar]] of shame",<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2012/mar/24/mail-online-sidebar-of-shame | title=The shocking thing about the Mail Online's sidebar of shame | first= Andrew | last= Brown | newspaper=The Guardian | date= 24 March 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | url=http://bjr.org.uk/data/2014/no3_kiss | title=A new medium seeks old skills | first=Jemima | last= Kiss | journal=British Journalism Review | volume=25 | number=3 | year=2014 | pages=33–38}}</ref> a box listing celebrity misdemeanours.<ref name=FT20140924 /> The ''[[Financial Times]]'' has suggested that "[[q:Samuel Johnson#Vol III|If you are tired]] of MailOnline, you are tired of [[Kim Kardashian]]’s life – and most readers are not";<ref name=FT20140924/> conversely [[George Clooney]] has described it as "the worst kind of tabloid. One that makes up its facts to the detriment of its readers" after it published an untrue story about his fiancée's family.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/jul/11/george-clooney-rejects-daily-mail-apology | title=George Clooney rejects Daily Mail apology, calling it 'worst kind of tabloid' | first=Roy | last= Greenslade | newspaper=The Guardian | date= 11 July 2014 }}</ref> The website reached 199.4 million [[Unique user|unique monthly visitors]] in December 2014,<ref>[https://www.journalism.co.uk/news/abc-mail-online-on-verge-of-reaching-200-million-monthly-visitors-in-december/s2/a563873/ Mail Online on verge of reaching 200 million monthly visitors in December] 22-January 2015</ref> up from 189.52 million in January 2014 and 128.59 million in May 2013,<ref>[http://www.pressgazette.co.uk/mail-online-soars-biggest-ever-traffic-total-129m-unique-browsers-worldwide Mail Online soars to biggest ever traffic total with 129m unique browsers worldwide] 20- June 2013</ref> according to the [[Audit Bureau of Circulations (UK)|Audit Bureau of Circulations]].<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.mediaweek.co.uk/article/1281725/newspaper-abcs-digital-statistics-january-2014|title= Newspaper ABCs: Digital statistics for January 2014 |accessdate= 24 February 2014|date= 20 February 2014}}</ref>
Globally, MailOnline is the most visited English-language newspaper website;<ref name=FT20140924/> [[ComScore]] gave the site 61.6 million unique desktop computer visitors for January 2014, ahead of ''[[The New York Times]]''' ''''' website, which received 41.97 million visitors in the same month'''''.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.mediaweek.co.uk/news/1066247/MailOnline-overtakes-Huffington-Post-become-worlds-no-2/ |title= MailOnline overtakes Huffington Post to become world's no 2 |accessdate= 18 May 2011|date= 19 April 2011|work= MediaWeek| location=London | first=Arif | last=Durrani}}</ref>''''' According to ComScore, MailOnline recorded 100.5 million visitors across desktop computers, smartphones and tablets in that month.<ref>[http://www.comscore.com/Insights/Press_Releases/2014/3/comScore_Innovates_to_Deliver_Single_Metric_for_Global_Multi-Platform_Audiences comScore Innovates to Deliver Single Metric for Global Multi-Platform Audiences] 31 March 2014</ref> In July 2014 it recorded 134 million users.<ref name="Royal Birth">{{cite web|title=Mail Online records 134m users in July|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/aug/05/mail-online-royal-birth|publisher=Guardian Online}}</ref>
Almost 70% of its traffic comes from outside the UK, mostly from the United States.<ref name=Guardian20140127>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/jan/27/mail-online-com-domain-name | title=Mail Online to switch to .com domain name | first= Mark | last= Sweney| newspaper=The Guardian | date= 27 January 2014}}</ref> The "Daily Mail" print newspaper has no presence there, but has aggressively targeted the country with its online offering, branded as the "Daily Mail" rather than MailOnline.<ref name=FT20140924/> In January 2014 it paid over £1m to the ''[[Charleston Daily Mail]]'' for the domain name www.dailymail.com in order to increase its attractiveness to US advertisers.<ref name=Guardian20140127 />
In January 2014, it was ranked the eighth most-visited news website in Australia, up from tenth in December 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mumbrella.com.au/news-com-au-regains-top-spot-read-website-mail-online-now-eighth-position-206878|title=News.com.au regains top spot as most read website, Mail Online now in eighth position|work=mUmBRELLA}}</ref> Globally the site was forecast to reach £60m in advertising sales in the year to September 2014, up 49%.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/8121578c-3e37-11e4-b7fc-00144feabdc0.html | title=DMGT suffers further software headaches | date=17 September 2014 | first=Henry | last= Mance | newspaper=Financial Times}}</ref> £35m has been invested in creating the site.<ref name=FT20140924/> The site has introduced sponsored articles, with a guarantee of 450,000 page views at a cost of £65,000 per article.<ref name=FT20140924/>
==Content==
MailOnline features a broad mixture of international news, and carries mainly UK-focused coverage of sport, personal finance, travel, celebrity news, science and lifestyle editorial. As of September 2014, it employs 615 people, including 406 editorial staff.<ref name=FT20140924/> These create over 750 articles per day,<ref name=FT20140924/> the editorial stance of which broadly reflects that of the ''Daily Mail'', being to the [[Right-wing politics|right wing]] of mainstream British politics and typically supporting the [[UK Conservative Party]].<ref>{{cite news|author=This Is Money |url=https://www.dailymail.co.uk/pages/live/articles/news/newscomment.html?in_article_id=347259&in_page_id=1787&in_a_source= |title=Charges take the shine off Ashanti |work=Daily Mail |date=5 August 2002 |accessdate=23 August 2013}}</ref> MailOnline articles tend to be dominated by pictures rather than long-form journalism.<ref name="BBC20120127">{{cite news|last=Wheeler |first=Brian |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-16746785 |title=How the Daily Mail stormed the US |publisher=BBC News |date=27 January 2012 |accessdate=23 August 2013}}</ref>
A major component of the website is its entertainment news, often featuring celebrities such as [[Kim Kardashian]]<ref>{{cite news|first=Lizzie |last=Smith |url=https://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2380885/Kim-Kardashian-plots-post-baby-public-appearance-ahead-sister-Kylie-Jenners-Sweet-16.html |title=Kim Kardashian plots her first post-baby public appearance ahead of sister Kylie Jenner's Sweet 16 |publisher=MailOnline |date=30 July 2013 |accessdate=23 August 2013}}</ref> or members of the [[British Royal Family]] such as the [[Duchess of Cambridge]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Bianca |last=London |url=https://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-2380474/Princess-Beatrice-boyfriend-Dave-Clark-rule-waves-South-France.html |title=Princess Beatrice makes waves in £15 bikini and stylish kaftan as she hits the beach in St Tropez with boyfriend Dave Clark |work=Daily Mail |date=30 July 2013 |accessdate=23 August 2013}}</ref> It is estimated that 25% of the traffic received by the website is purely to access the entertainment and gossip stories.<ref name="Robinson20101115">{{cite news|first=James |last=Robinson |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/nov/15/mailonline-daily-mail-website |title=MailOnline: what is the secret of its success? |newspaper=The Guardian |date=15 November 2010 |accessdate=23 August 2013}}</ref>
The website allows users to create accounts in order to comment on articles, and also allows anyone to express anonymous approval or disapproval of comments made. ==Sourcing==
In March 2012, the [[Poynter Institute]] published an article criticising the MailOnline for failing to give proper attribution to the sources of some article content, and often reprinting paragraphs without permission or attribution. The article said that when the MailOnline is called out for stealing content, it will sometime removes the text in question without acknowledging or apologising for the problem.<ref name="poynter"/>
Martin Clarke, editor of MailOnline, said, "We will soon be introducing features that will allow us to link easily and prominently to other sites when further recognition of source material is needed."<ref name="poynter">{{cite web|title=Editor of Daily Mail’s website defends attribution practices in face of growing criticism|url=http://www.poynter.org/latest-news/regret-the-error/167767/editor-of-daily-mails-website-defends-attribution-policy-in-face-of-growing-crticisim|publisher=poynter.org|accessdate=6 January 2013}}</ref> However, by July 2013, MailOnline articles, including main articles, still did not contain any links to original sources or tips.<ref>{{cite news|last=Sinmaz|first=Emine|title=MailOnline article showing no links|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2377154/Eight-ton-orca-leaps-15ft-air-finally-capture-dolphin-hour-chase.html|publisher=MailOnline|accessdate=25 July 2013|date=24 July 2013}}</ref>
In 2015, James King, who left the MailOnline after a year as a reporter, said that the editorial model of the Mail depended on "dishonesty, theft of copyrighted material, and sensationalism so absurd that it crosses into fabrication". King worked as a contractor, and declined a full-time job because he did not want to put his byline on his stories.<ref>[http://tktk.gawker.com/my-year-ripping-off-the-web-with-the-daily-mail-online-1689453286 My Year Ripping Off the Web With the Daily Mail Online] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905103217/http://tktk.gawker.com/my-year-ripping-off-the-web-with-the-daily-mail-online-1689453286 |date=5 September 2015 }}, James King, Gawker, 4 March 2015</ref>
